resource.chars: J. S. James carried over this 2sol note from nineteenth-century editions of The Sacred Harp (1844–70). Making an awkward leap from its preceding tone and forming a discordant interval with the other three parts, the retention of this error demonstrates the extent to which Original Sacred Harp editors avoided altering their source material, even when it was visibly incorrect. This reticence might be attributed to a hasty editorial process, but was also in alignment with the editors’ musical conservatism. The note was later corrected to the 5sol by editors of the 1966 edition of Original Sacred Harp.

resource.chars: J. S. James’s biographies of Thomas Ken and Guillaume Franc narratively connect Original Sacred Harp to renowned European figures and places. James paints a compelling picture of the hymn writers and religious leaders of “Christendom,” but the devil lies in his incorrect details. Although Ken wrote the text most frequently paired with this tune—“Praise God from whom all blessings flow”—that lyric does not appear here. “Old Hundred” was itself added to the Genevan Psalter in 1551 after the period during which Guillaume Franc was contributing to it. Yet biographies of these figures advance James’s effort to elevate the status of Sacred Harp singing by associating the tunebook with these leading European and Christian figures.

Sacred Harp compiler B. F. White included “Mear” in the 1844 first edition of The Sacred Harp and made no changes to the song in subsequent editions. J. S. James’s inaccurate statement to the contrary is remarkably specific, consistent with attributions elsewhere in Original Sacred Harp where James arbitrarily selected a date of composition a couple of years off from the publication date of an edition of The Sacred Harp. James’s claim here may represent an attempt to exaggerate White’s role in shaping the tunebook’s contents and it contributes to James’s goal of binding White and the tunebook more closely to the distant and prestigious people, places, and times associated with “Mear.”

References

W. M. Cooper, ed., The Sacred Harp (Dothan, AL: W. M. Cooper, 1902), 49; William Walker, ed., The Christian Harmony (Philadelphia: E. W. Miller Co., 1873), 59.

S. M. Denson arranged the alto line for “Mear” by stitching together components of William Walker’s alto part (printed in the 1867 Christian Harmony) and that of B. P. Poyner (included in W. M. Cooper’s 1902 Sacred Harp). Every note in Denson’s alto matches the corresponding note in one or both of these two sources. As illustrated in the diagram below, Denson mostly drew on Walker’s alto for the first three phrases of the song, while selecting Poyner’s alto for much of the song’s final phrase. Denson’s selections from each source indicate a preference for a lower range and for melodic movement over notes repeated on the same scale degree.

References

W. M. Cooper, ed., The Sacred Harp (Dothan, AL: W. M. Cooper, 1902), 49; William Walker, ed., The Christian Harmony (Philadelphia: E. W. Miller Co., 1873), 59.
